hints_raw: Recall the answer from part (a) of this question.  Does one of those requirements fail?
question: 2 (c)
sols_html: In order for a function to be continuous on the interval \(( - \infty, \infty )\) it must be defined everywhere. However, in the previous part of the question, we just showed that g is not defined at an infinite number of points. Thus g is not continuous on \((- \infty, \infty)\).
sols_latex:
In order for a function to be continuous on the interval
$( - \infty, \infty )$ it must be defined everywhere. However, in the
previous part of the question, we just showed that \emph{g} is not
defined at an infinite number of points. Thus \emph{g} is not continuous
on $(- \infty, \infty)$.
sols_raw: In order for a function to be continuous on the interval <math>( - \infty, \infty ) </math> it must be defined everywhere.  However, in the previous part of the question, we just showed that ''g'' is not defined at an infinite number of points.  Thus ''g'' is not continuous on <math>(- \infty, \infty) </math>.
statement_html:
Is

\[\begin{aligned} g(x) = \frac{1}{\sin (x)}\end{aligned}\]

continuous on the interval \((-\infty, \infty)\)? Why or why not?
statement_raw:
Is 
: <math>g(x) = \frac{1}{\sin (x)} </math> 
continuous on the interval <math>(-\infty, \infty)</math>?  Why or why not?
